title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma, or olfactory neuroblastoma, is a rare malignant neoplasm of the sinonasal tract originating from the olfactory neuroepithelium with neuroblastic differentiation. It most often presents in the superior nasal cavity. It is a locally aggressive neoplasm and metastasizes via both hematogenous and lymphatic routes. This activity reviews the evaluation, diagnosis, and management of esthesioneuroblastoma and the role of team-based interprofessional care for affected patients.

It most often presents in the superior nasal cavity. It is a locally aggressive neoplasm and metastasizes via both hematogenous and lymphatic routes. This activity reviews the evaluation, diagnosis, and management of esthesioneuroblastoma and the role of team-based interprofessional care for affected patients.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Continuing Education Activity
content: Objectives: Explain the typical presentation of esthesioneuroblastoma. Review the evaluation of esthesioneuroblastoma. Explain how to manage esthesioneuroblastoma. Describe an optimally functioning interprofessional team approach to coordinate care and enhance outcomes for patients with esthesioneuroblastoma. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Continuing Education Activity. Objectives: Explain the typical presentation of esthesioneuroblastoma. Review the evaluation of esthesioneuroblastoma. Explain how to manage esthesioneuroblastoma. Describe an optimally functioning interprofessional team approach to coordinate care and enhance outcomes for patients with esthesioneuroblastoma. Access free multiple choice questions on this topic.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Introduction
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma, or olfactory neuroblastoma, is a rare malignant neoplasm of the sinonasal tract originating from the olfactory neuroepithelium with neuroblastic differentiation. It most often presents in the superior nasal cavity. Since its initial description in 1924 by Berger and Luc, there have been reports of more than 1000 cases of esthesioneuroblastoma worldwide. [1] Esthesioneuroblastoma is a locally aggressive neoplasm and metastasizes by both hematogenous and lymphatic routes.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Introduction. Esthesioneuroblastoma, or olfactory neuroblastoma, is a rare malignant neoplasm of the sinonasal tract originating from the olfactory neuroepithelium with neuroblastic differentiation. It most often presents in the superior nasal cavity. Since its initial description in 1924 by Berger and Luc, there have been reports of more than 1000 cases of esthesioneuroblastoma worldwide. [1] Esthesioneuroblastoma is a locally aggressive neoplasm and metastasizes by both hematogenous and lymphatic routes.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Etiology
content: The exact etiology of esthesioneuroblastoma is still unknown, and so are the predisposing factors.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Etiology. The exact etiology of esthesioneuroblastoma is still unknown, and so are the predisposing factors.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Epidemiology
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma accounts for 2% to 6% of nasal cavity and paranasal sinus cancer cases and 0.3% of all upper aerodigestive tract malignancies. [2] The incidence of esthesioneuroblastoma seems to have increased in the last decade. Esthesioneuroblastoma may occur at any age, although it occurs predominantly in young adults. The mean age at presentation is 40 to 70 years. There is a second peak of incidence in later adult life. Men and women are affected equally. [3]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Epidemiology. Esthesioneuroblastoma accounts for 2% to 6% of nasal cavity and paranasal sinus cancer cases and 0.3% of all upper aerodigestive tract malignancies. [2] The incidence of esthesioneuroblastoma seems to have increased in the last decade. Esthesioneuroblastoma may occur at any age, although it occurs predominantly in young adults. The mean age at presentation is 40 to 70 years. There is a second peak of incidence in later adult life. Men and women are affected equally. [3]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Pathophysiology
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma is thought to arise from specialized sensory neuroepithelial olfactory cells. These cells are normally present in the upper part of the nasal cavity, including the upper part of the septum, superior nasal concha, the roof of the nose, and the cribriform plate of the ethmoid sinus.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Pathophysiology. Esthesioneuroblastoma is thought to arise from specialized sensory neuroepithelial olfactory cells. These cells are normally present in the upper part of the nasal cavity, including the upper part of the septum, superior nasal concha, the roof of the nose, and the cribriform plate of the ethmoid sinus.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Pathophysiology -- Genetic profile:
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma demonstrates numerous chromosomal aberrations, deletions, and gains, but with no consistent pattern. [4] [5] In one study, a specific deletion on chromosome 11 and a gain on chromosome 1p correlated with metastasis and a worse prognosis. [6] Gains are more frequent than losses, and high-stage esthesioneuroblastomas show more alterations than low-stage tumors. Gains in 20q and 13q may be significant in the progression of this neoplasm - these regions may harbor genes with functional relevance in esthesioneuroblastoma. The detection of PTCH1, GL/1, and GL/2 in 70%, 70%, and 65%, respectively, of human esthesioneuroblastoma specimens, suggests that the SHH signaling pathway may be involved in the pathogenesis of this neoplasm. [7] Research has found expression of the OMP and RICBB genes in esthesioneuroblastomas.

[4] [5] In one study, a specific deletion on chromosome 11 and a gain on chromosome 1p correlated with metastasis and a worse prognosis. [6] Gains are more frequent than losses, and high-stage esthesioneuroblastomas show more alterations than low-stage tumors. Gains in 20q and 13q may be significant in the progression of this neoplasm - these regions may harbor genes with functional relevance in esthesioneuroblastoma. The detection of PTCH1, GL/1, and GL/2 in 70%, 70%, and 65%, respectively, of human esthesioneuroblastoma specimens, suggests that the SHH signaling pathway may be involved in the pathogenesis of this neoplasm. [7] Research has found expression of the OMP and RICBB genes in esthesioneuroblastomas.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Histopathology -- Macroscopic examination:
content: Esthesioneuroblastomas are usually unilateral, polypoid, glistening, soft, reddish-grey masses with an intact mucosa; the cut surface appears greyish-tan to pinkish-red and hyper vascularized. The tumors range from under 1 cm in size to large masses involving the nasal cavity and intracranial region. They frequently expand into the adjacent paranasal sinuses, orbit, and cranial vault. [8]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Histopathology -- Macroscopic examination:. Esthesioneuroblastomas are usually unilateral, polypoid, glistening, soft, reddish-grey masses with an intact mucosa; the cut surface appears greyish-tan to pinkish-red and hyper vascularized. The tumors range from under 1 cm in size to large masses involving the nasal cavity and intracranial region. They frequently expand into the adjacent paranasal sinuses, orbit, and cranial vault. [8]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Histopathology -- Macroscopic examination:
content: Low-grade esthesioneuroblastoma form submucosal, sharply demarcated nests, lobules, or sheets of cells, often separated by richly vascular or hyalinized fibrous stroma. Pseudorosettes (Homer-Wright rosettes), with neoplastic cells palisading or cuffed around the central delicate fibrillar neural matrix, may be seen. The tumor cells are often uniform, with sparse cytoplasm and round or ovoid nuclei with punctate salt-and-pepper chromatin and nucleoli that are either small or absent. Esthesioneuroblastoma characteristically demonstrates fibrillary cytoplasm and interdigitating neuronal processes (neuropil), created by a syncytium of cells. Higher-grade tumors show tumor necrosis, pleomorphism, increased mitoses, decreased to absent neuropil, and a less overt lobular growth pattern. The tumor cells can arrange in gland-like rings or tight annular formations with a true lumen (Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes). Rosettes alone are not diagnostic of esthesioneuroblastoma, although the Homer Wright rosettes are nearly pathognomonic in the nasal cavity when containing true neuropil. The mitotic rate is variable, but is usually low, especially in lower-grade tumors. Calcifications (concretion-like or psammomatous) may be seen, less frequently as the grade increases. Melanin pigment, ganglion cells, rhabdomyoblasts, divergent differentiation as islands of true epithelium (squamous pearls or gland formation), and clear-cell change may occasionally present in esthesioneuroblastoma. [8]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Histopathology -- Macroscopic examination:. Low-grade esthesioneuroblastoma form submucosal, sharply demarcated nests, lobules, or sheets of cells, often separated by richly vascular or hyalinized fibrous stroma. Pseudorosettes (Homer-Wright rosettes), with neoplastic cells palisading or cuffed around the central delicate fibrillar neural matrix, may be seen. The tumor cells are often uniform, with sparse cytoplasm and round or ovoid nuclei with punctate salt-and-pepper chromatin and nucleoli that are either small or absent. Esthesioneuroblastoma characteristically demonstrates fibrillary cytoplasm and interdigitating neuronal processes (neuropil), created by a syncytium of cells. Higher-grade tumors show tumor necrosis, pleomorphism, increased mitoses, decreased to absent neuropil, and a less overt lobular growth pattern. The tumor cells can arrange in gland-like rings or tight annular formations with a true lumen (Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes). Rosettes alone are not diagnostic of esthesioneuroblastoma, although the Homer Wright rosettes are nearly pathognomonic in the nasal cavity when containing true neuropil. The mitotic rate is variable, but is usually low, especially in lower-grade tumors. Calcifications (concretion-like or psammomatous) may be seen, less frequently as the grade increases. Melanin pigment, ganglion cells, rhabdomyoblasts, divergent differentiation as islands of true epithelium (squamous pearls or gland formation), and clear-cell change may occasionally present in esthesioneuroblastoma. [8]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Histopathology -- Immunohistochemical study:
content: The typical immunohistochemical profile includes diffuse staining for neuron-specific enolase, [9] synaptophysin, chromogranin A, CD56 (NCAM) and beta-tubulin, as well as variable S100 protein reactivity, which is typically in a sustentacular cell pattern highlighting only cells at the periphery of the nests, often limited in higher-grade tumors. Sustentacular cells may also be positive for GFAP. Calretinin staining (nuclear and cytoplasmic) has been reported in esthesioneuroblastoma but can also be seen in other sinonasal tumors. [10] As many as one-third of esthesioneuroblastomas may also stain focally for cytokeratin (CAM5.2, CK18). Negative markers include CD45RB, CD99, p63, and FLl1. Proliferation marker studies reveal a variable  Ki-67 proliferation index (2- 50%), and BCL2 expression increases with tumor grade. [11] [12]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Histopathology -- Immunohistochemical study:. The typical immunohistochemical profile includes diffuse staining for neuron-specific enolase, [9] synaptophysin, chromogranin A, CD56 (NCAM) and beta-tubulin, as well as variable S100 protein reactivity, which is typically in a sustentacular cell pattern highlighting only cells at the periphery of the nests, often limited in higher-grade tumors. Sustentacular cells may also be positive for GFAP. Calretinin staining (nuclear and cytoplasmic) has been reported in esthesioneuroblastoma but can also be seen in other sinonasal tumors. [10] As many as one-third of esthesioneuroblastomas may also stain focally for cytokeratin (CAM5.2, CK18). Negative markers include CD45RB, CD99, p63, and FLl1. Proliferation marker studies reveal a variable  Ki-67 proliferation index (2- 50%), and BCL2 expression increases with tumor grade. [11] [12]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- History and Physical
content: Clinically, esthesioneuroblastoma often has a subtle presentation mimicking benign inflammatory or infectious disease, and delay in diagnosis is not uncommon. Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are typical early manifestations; however, other more specific symptoms can occur depending on the location and extent of the tumor. [13] Anosmia can precede the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma by several years. [14] Other symptoms are related to extension into paranasal sinuses (facial swelling, medial canthus mass), the orbit (orbital pain, proptosis, epiphora, visual field defects), or anterior cranial fossa (headache), and manifestations of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- History and Physical. Clinically, esthesioneuroblastoma often has a subtle presentation mimicking benign inflammatory or infectious disease, and delay in diagnosis is not uncommon. Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are typical early manifestations; however, other more specific symptoms can occur depending on the location and extent of the tumor. [13] Anosmia can precede the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma by several years. [14] Other symptoms are related to extension into paranasal sinuses (facial swelling, medial canthus mass), the orbit (orbital pain, proptosis, epiphora, visual field defects), or anterior cranial fossa (headache), and manifestations of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation
content: A thorough physical exam and flexible fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation, complemented with both contrast-enhanced CT scan and MR imaging, are key in the diagnostic workup.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation. A thorough physical exam and flexible fiberoptic endoscopic evaluation, complemented with both contrast-enhanced CT scan and MR imaging, are key in the diagnostic workup.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Physical exam:
content: Any patient with a history that is suspicious for a sinonasal tumor requires a thorough neurologic, ophthalmologic, and head and neck examination.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Physical exam:. Any patient with a history that is suspicious for a sinonasal tumor requires a thorough neurologic, ophthalmologic, and head and neck examination.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Computed tomography (CT) scan:
content: Radiographic assessment of esthesioneuroblastoma begins with a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan. Sinus disease and bony erosion depict well with CT scans. [8]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Computed tomography (CT) scan:. Radiographic assessment of esthesioneuroblastoma begins with a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan. Sinus disease and bony erosion depict well with CT scans. [8]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Magnetic resonance imaging:
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma is most typically hypointense compared with brain gray matter on T1-weighted MRI and should enhance with gadolinium. T2-weighted images show an isointense or hyperintense mass. MRI provides better discrimination between tumor and secretions and optimal evaluation of orbital and intracranial or brain parenchymal involvement. [8]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Magnetic resonance imaging:. Esthesioneuroblastoma is most typically hypointense compared with brain gray matter on T1-weighted MRI and should enhance with gadolinium. T2-weighted images show an isointense or hyperintense mass. MRI provides better discrimination between tumor and secretions and optimal evaluation of orbital and intracranial or brain parenchymal involvement. [8]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Nuclear medicine scan: [15]
content: Most of these tumors are MIBG-avid, which can be used to differentiate them from anterior cranial fossa meningiomas.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Nuclear medicine scan: [15]. Most of these tumors are MIBG-avid, which can be used to differentiate them from anterior cranial fossa meningiomas.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Biopsy of the tumor:
content: Intraoperative biopsy under general anesthesia for the sinonasal mass is recommended. The biopsy is preferably performed after imaging studies have been reviewed to determine the vascularity of the mass. [8]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Evaluation -- Biopsy of the tumor:. Intraoperative biopsy under general anesthesia for the sinonasal mass is recommended. The biopsy is preferably performed after imaging studies have been reviewed to determine the vascularity of the mass. [8]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Treatment / Management
content: The three options used for the treatment of esthesioneuroblastoma are surgery, external beam radiation, and chemotherapy. Often, the treatment utilizes a combination of these modalities. [8] [16] For small tumors with no sign of regional or local metastasis, surgical resection is advocated. [8] More extensive surgery, typically an open or open or endoscopic-assisted craniofacial resection is recommended along with postoperative radiation therapy, as the disease becomes more locally advanced. [8] [17] Preoperative radiation is an alternative strategy that may yield equivalent results, and induction chemotherapy, as well as concurrent postoperative chemoradiation, may improve local, regional, and distant control. [8] Patients with distant disease can have palliative therapy. Chemoradiation is an approach for patients with unresectable local disease, which could subsequently improve the resectability for locally-advanced esthesioneuroblastoma. [8] [18]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Treatment / Management. The three options used for the treatment of esthesioneuroblastoma are surgery, external beam radiation, and chemotherapy. Often, the treatment utilizes a combination of these modalities. [8] [16] For small tumors with no sign of regional or local metastasis, surgical resection is advocated. [8] More extensive surgery, typically an open or open or endoscopic-assisted craniofacial resection is recommended along with postoperative radiation therapy, as the disease becomes more locally advanced. [8] [17] Preoperative radiation is an alternative strategy that may yield equivalent results, and induction chemotherapy, as well as concurrent postoperative chemoradiation, may improve local, regional, and distant control. [8] Patients with distant disease can have palliative therapy. Chemoradiation is an approach for patients with unresectable local disease, which could subsequently improve the resectability for locally-advanced esthesioneuroblastoma. [8] [18]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Differential Diagnosis -- Malignant neoplasms [8] :
content: Extramedullary plasmacytoma Extraosseous Ewing sarcoma/Primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) Mesenchymal chondrosarcoma Natural killer/T-cell lymphoma Rhabdomyosarcoma Sinonasal malignant melanoma Sinonasal neuroendocrine carcinoma Sinonasal undifferentiated carcinoma Small cell osteosarcoma Small cell undifferentiated (neuroendocrine) carcinoma Synovial sarcoma Undifferentiated (lymphoepithelioma like) carcinoma
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Differential Diagnosis -- Malignant neoplasms [8] :. Extramedullary plasmacytoma Extraosseous Ewing sarcoma/Primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) Mesenchymal chondrosarcoma Natural killer/T-cell lymphoma Rhabdomyosarcoma Sinonasal malignant melanoma Sinonasal neuroendocrine carcinoma Sinonasal undifferentiated carcinoma Small cell osteosarcoma Small cell undifferentiated (neuroendocrine) carcinoma Synovial sarcoma Undifferentiated (lymphoepithelioma like) carcinoma

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Staging
content: Hyams et al. developed the most widely used grading system for esthesioneuroblastoma. [13] This system divides the spectrum of esthesioneuroblastoma maturation into four grades, ranging from most differentiated (grade I) to least differentiated (grade IV), based on tumor architecture, mitotic activity, nuclear pleomorphism, fibrillary matrix and rosettes, necrosis, gland proliferation, and calcifications. This grading scheme had independent validation relative to prognosis. [13] [19] The Kadish staging system is an effective means to predict disease-free survival and is widely accepted. It includes the following groups: Group A tumors: are limited to the nasal cavity Group B tumors: extend only to the paranasal sinus Group C tumors: extend beyond the nasal cavity and sinuses A modified Kadish system includes group D tumors, which have distant metastasis or cervical lymphadenopathy.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Staging. Hyams et al. developed the most widely used grading system for esthesioneuroblastoma. [13] This system divides the spectrum of esthesioneuroblastoma maturation into four grades, ranging from most differentiated (grade I) to least differentiated (grade IV), based on tumor architecture, mitotic activity, nuclear pleomorphism, fibrillary matrix and rosettes, necrosis, gland proliferation, and calcifications. This grading scheme had independent validation relative to prognosis. [13] [19] The Kadish staging system is an effective means to predict disease-free survival and is widely accepted. It includes the following groups: Group A tumors: are limited to the nasal cavity Group B tumors: extend only to the paranasal sinus Group C tumors: extend beyond the nasal cavity and sinuses A modified Kadish system includes group D tumors, which have distant metastasis or cervical lymphadenopathy.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Staging
content: Dulguerov also proposed a TNM (tumor/nodes/metastasis) style staging system allowing the inclusion of nodal status. This system was later reported to correlate closely with survival and recurrence. [20] [21]
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Staging. Dulguerov also proposed a TNM (tumor/nodes/metastasis) style staging system allowing the inclusion of nodal status. This system was later reported to correlate closely with survival and recurrence. [20] [21]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Prognosis
content: The prognosis of esthesioneuroblastoma is both stage- and grade-dependent. The 5-year survival of stage A tumors is 75% to 90% whereas stage C has a 45% survival. Likewise, high-grade tumors have a 25% 5-year survival whereas low-grade tumors have an 80% survival [8] . Poor prognostic indicators of esthesioneuroblastoma include [8] : Metastases High stage High-grade tumor Above 50 or below 20 or years of age at presentation Intracranial spread High proliferation Females Polyploidy/aneuploidy
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Prognosis. The prognosis of esthesioneuroblastoma is both stage- and grade-dependent. The 5-year survival of stage A tumors is 75% to 90% whereas stage C has a 45% survival. Likewise, high-grade tumors have a 25% 5-year survival whereas low-grade tumors have an 80% survival [8] . Poor prognostic indicators of esthesioneuroblastoma include [8] : Metastases High stage High-grade tumor Above 50 or below 20 or years of age at presentation Intracranial spread High proliferation Females Polyploidy/aneuploidy

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Complications
content: Recurrence of esthesioneuroblastoma is common, usually occurs within 2 years of the initial presentation (about 30%). Metastasis develops in 35% of cases. The cervical lymph nodes are the most common site of spread. Distant metastasis occurs in approximately 10% of patients (lung, bone, liver, skin). [1]

Metastasis develops in 35% of cases. The cervical lymph nodes are the most common site of spread. Distant metastasis occurs in approximately 10% of patients (lung, bone, liver, skin). [1]

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Consultations
content: Otolaryngologist Neurosurgeon Radiation oncologist Oncologist
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Consultations. Otolaryngologist Neurosurgeon Radiation oncologist Oncologist

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Deterrence and Patient Education
content: Patients and their families require education on how to recognize the early signs and symptoms of sinonasal tumors. Patients with signs of nasal obstruction, epistaxis, or anosmia, should seek early intervention. Health education promoting prompt presentation to hospitals, and efforts at early detection of esthesioneuroblastoma are necessary to achieve the cure.
contents: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Deterrence and Patient Education. Patients and their families require education on how to recognize the early signs and symptoms of sinonasal tumors. Patients with signs of nasal obstruction, epistaxis, or anosmia, should seek early intervention. Health education promoting prompt presentation to hospitals, and efforts at early detection of esthesioneuroblastoma are necessary to achieve the cure.

title: Esthesioneuroblastoma -- Enhancing Healthcare Team Outcomes
content: Esthesioneuroblastoma is a rare disease that requires multi-institutional and international collaboration. An interprofessional team approach provides the best outcomes. Centralized processing of esthesioneuroblastoma cases would offer the most favorable ground to accrue more patients and use a uniform database in collecting information and reporting outcomes. [13] Due to the aggressive nature of esthesioneuroblastoma, prompt diagnosis is critical in determining appropriate treatment options. The primary care provider and nurse practitioner should promptly refer any patient with a suspected nasal mass to the otolaryngologist for further workup. Management of esthesioneuroblastoma is complex and needs an interprofessional approach involving a team that consists of an otolaryngologist, a neurosurgeon, a radiation oncologist, a pathologist, a radiologist, and an oncologist, with support from nursing and pharmacy, where indicated, as treatment moves forward. Specialty care nurses and pharmacists can be integral parts of the team. Pharmacists review medications, detect drug-drug interactions and provide patient education. Specialty trained nurses in otolaryngology and oncology are involved in the initial evaluation, monitor patients, patient education, and supply updated information to the team. [Level 5]

Specialty care nurses and pharmacists can be integral parts of the team. Pharmacists review medications, detect drug-drug interactions and provide patient education.
